author: sli
fields.title: Git Tutorial

fields.document:
=== Get Prepared

* Try out the [[https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.4/|Django]] tutorials.
* The website front end is based on [[http://twitter.github.com/bootstrap/|Bootstrap]].
* The CSS is generated from [[http://lesscss.org/|LESS]] files.
* Acquire basic knowledge of [[http://docs.jquery.com/Tutorials|JQuery]].
* Awesome examples of the [[http://www.dajaxproject.com/|AJAX framework]] we are using.

=== Project Overview

* //bulletin// - code related to the Bulletin component
* //portfolio// - code related to the Portfolio component
* //data// - views which return only data instead of pages
* //homeroom// - code related to the Crowd component
* //account// - code related to an user account, including authentication and registration
* //backstage// - code related to the Backstage component
* //core// - fundamental code required by other components
** //management// - where custom Django management commands go
** //templatetags// - where template tags/filters go
* //course// - code related to course information
* //schoolax// - main website
** //assets// - website's static files
** //fixtures// - partial or complete database dumps
** //templates// - HTML templates which get displayed

=== Changes to Models

* If a change to a model which may affect the database schema is made, we will have to utilize South to migrate the schema and data.
* Pull the latest version of the code (VERY IMPORTANT), so we do not get migration conflicts.
* Type ##python manage.py migrate## to synchronize the database to the latest version.
* Type ##python manage.py schemamigration [the app which the model is in] --auto##.
* Define any required default values.
* Type ##python manage.py migrate## again.
* If no error occurs, you can now commit and push your code along with the generated migration Python files.
* To rename a database table:
{{{
python manage.py schemamigration yourapp rename_foo_to_bar --empty

# Inside the generated migration file
class Migration(SchemaMigration):
    def forwards(self, orm):
        db.rename_table('yourapp_foo', 'yourapp_bar')
    def backwards(self, orm):
        db.rename_table('yourapp_bar','yourapp_foo') 
}}}
* Any other usage can refer to the [[http://south.aeracode.org/docs/index.html|South documentation]].

=== Dump Data Fixture

* Go to project directory //Minerva/tools//.
* Type ##python dumpdata.py##.
* Input a fixture collection name when prompted.
* Wait till the JSON data files are generated.

=== Search Engine

* We are currently using the Whoosh search engine.
* Type ##python manage.py rebuild_index## to rebuild search index.
* Type ##python manage.py update_index## to update search index.

=== Generate CSS Files

* We are using the LESS framework, which needs to be compiled to prepare the CSS files for non-development environments, using LESS compilers.
** [[http://winless.org/|WinLess]] (Windows)
** [[http://crunchapp.net/|Crunch]] (Mac)
** [[http://wearekiss.com/simpless|SimpLess]] (Cross-Platform)
* After installing the LESS compiler, just compile the //minerva.less// file and put the generated //minerva.css// file into the //assets/css// folder.
author: sli
fields.title: Development Process

fields.document:
=== Install Python

# Type //python// in command prompt / terminal to see if Python is already installed.
# If not, download [[http://www.python.org/download/|Python version 2.7.x]] for your corresponding operating system.
# If you are on Windows, you might have to add //path\to\python// and //path\to\python\Scripts// to your system's Path environment variable if they are not there.
** Search //environment// in the search box in Start menu, and then click on //Edit the system environment variables//.
** Under //System variables//, click to edit //Path//.
** Paths are separated by //;//.
# Now type //python// in the command prompt, if you entered the Python shell, you have successfully set up Python and can type //quit()// to exit the shell.

=== Setup Git Project

# Register a [[https://github.com/|Github]] account and contact administrators for Git repository collaborator permissions.
# If you are using Windows, you can download the latest version of Git including Bash console from [[http://code.google.com/p/msysgit/downloads/list|here]]. Git should be installed by default for Mac and Linux.
# Follow these [[http://help.github.com/win-set-up-git/|instructions]] to set up your SSH key with Github.
# In command prompt, go to the directory where you want to place the project repository.
# Type ##git clone git@github.com:Elesant/Minerva.git##.
# Now you have the source code for the Minerva project.

=== Setup Database

# Download and install [[http://www.postgresql.org/download/|PostgreSQL]] for your corresponding operating system.
# Open the management console //pgAdmin III//.
# If your //Server Groups// on the left panel is empty, click //File->Add Server// and create a new server with any name and set //Host// to //localhost// and leave //Port// at //5432// and input your password specified during PostgreSQL installation.
# Right click on //Login Roles// on the left panel and click on //New Login Role//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.


=== Install Python Modules

# Download [[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip#downloads|Pip]].
# Go to the downloaded Pip directory and type //python setup.py install//.
# Go to the project directory //Minerva/tools//.
# Type ##pip install -r requirements.txt## to install all required Python modules.
** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

==== Python Module List

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)
* Docutils (Documentation) - NOTE: Has to be installed using Python 3!
* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Troubleshooting

==== PostgreSQL on Ubuntu

##sudo apt-get install postgresql phppgadmin pgadmin3##

==== Cannot Login to pgAdmin

{{{
sudo -u postgres createuser --superuser any_user_name
sudo -u postgres psql
postgres=# \password any_user_name
}}}
Now you can set a new password for //any_user_name//.

==== Error Installing psycopg2 Python Module

##sudo apt-get install python-dev libpq-dev##

==== Permission Denied Errors

Run commands with //sudo//.

==== Database on Different Host & Port

If error related to database authentication failure occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. 
{{{
# settings_extra.py
from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host'
DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port'
}}}

For Mac OS, change HOST to '/tmp/' and PORT to 5432

=== Customized Settings Example

{{{
# Create a settings_extra.py under the same directory as the rest of the settings files

from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = '1337'
SWAP_USER = False
ENABLE_TOOLBAR = True

def toolbar_callback(request):
    return ENABLE_TOOLBAR

DEBUG_TOOLBAR_CONFIG = {
    'INTERCEPT_REDIRECTS': True,
    'SHOW_TOOLBAR_CALLBACK': toolbar_callback,
    'ENABLE_STACKTRACES': True,
}
}}}

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# If an error related to database occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Install Python

# Type //python// in command prompt / terminal to see if Python is already installed.
# If not, download [[http://www.python.org/download/|Python version 2.7.x]] for your corresponding operating system.
# If you are on Windows, you might have to add //path\to\python// and //path\to\python\Scripts// to your system's Path environment variable if they are not there.
** Search //environment// in the search box in Start menu, and then click on //Edit the system environment variables//.
** Under //System variables//, click to edit //Path//.
** Paths are separated by //;//.
# Now type //python// in the command prompt, if you entered the Python shell, you have successfully set up Python and can type //quit()// to exit the shell.

=== Setup Git Project

# Register a [[https://github.com/|Github]] account and contact administrators for Git repository collaborator permissions.
# If you are using Windows, you can download the latest version of Git including Bash console from [[http://code.google.com/p/msysgit/downloads/list|here]]. Git should be installed by default for Mac and Linux.
# Follow these [[http://help.github.com/win-set-up-git/|instructions]] to set up your SSH key with Github.
# In command prompt, go to the directory where you want to place the project repository.
# Type ##git clone git@github.com:Elesant/Minerva.git##.
# Now you have the source code for the Minerva project.

=== Setup Database

# Download and install [[http://www.postgresql.org/download/|PostgreSQL]] for your corresponding operating system.
# Open the management console //pgAdmin III//.
# If your //Server Groups// on the left panel is empty, click //File->Add Server// and create a new server with any name and set //Host// to //localhost// and leave //Port// at //5432// and input your password specified during PostgreSQL installation.
# Right click on //Login Roles// on the left panel and click on //New Login Role//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.


=== Install Python Modules

# Download [[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip#downloads|Pip]].
# Go to the downloaded Pip directory and type //python setup.py install//.
# Go to the project directory //Minerva/tools//.
# Type ##pip install -r requirements.txt## to install all required Python modules.
** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)

* PEP8 (Python Style Check)

* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

# In command prompt, go to the directory where you want to place the project repository.
# Type ##git clone git@github.com:Elesant/Minerva.git##.
# Now you have the source code for the Minerva project.

=== Setup Database

# Download and install [[http://www.postgresql.org/download/|PostgreSQL]] for your corresponding operating system.
# Open the management console //pgAdmin III//.
# If your //Server Groups// on the left panel is empty, click //File->Add Server// and create a new server with any name and set //Host// to //localhost// and leave //Port// at //5432// and input your password specified during PostgreSQL installation.
# Right click on //Login Roles// on the left panel and click on //New Login Role//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.


=== Install Python Modules

# Download [[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip#downloads|Pip]].
# Go to the downloaded Pip directory and type //python setup.py install//.
# Go to the project directory //Minerva/tools//.
# Type ##pip install -r requirements.txt## to install all required Python modules.
** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

==== Python Module List

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)
* Docutils (Documentation)
* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# If an error related to database occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. ## from settings import * DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host' DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port' ##
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)
* Docutils (Documentation)
* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Troubleshooting

If an error related to database occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. 
{{{
# settings_extra.py
from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host'
DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port'
}}}

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Troubleshooting

==== PostgreSQL on Ubuntu

##sudo apt-get install postgresql phppgadmin pgadmin3##

==== Cannot Login to pgAdmin

Check out the //Alternative Server Setup// section of [[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/PostgreSQL|this]] website.

==== Error Installing psycopg2 Python Module

##sudo apt-get install libpq-dev##

==== Database on Different Host and Port

If an error related to database occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. 
{{{
# settings_extra.py
from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host'
DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port'
}}}

=== Install Python

# Type //python// in command prompt / terminal to see if Python is already installed.
# If not, download [[http://www.python.org/download/|Python version 2.7.x]] for your corresponding operating system.
# If you are on Windows, you might have to add //path\to\python// and //path\to\python\Scripts// to your system's Path environment variable if they are not there.
** Search //environment// in the search box in Start menu, and then click on //Edit the system environment variables//.
** Under //System variables//, click to edit //Path//.
** Paths are separated by //;//.
# Now type //python// in the command prompt, if you entered the Python shell, you have successfully set up Python and can type //quit()// to exit the shell.

=== Setup Git Project

# Register a [[https://github.com/|Github]] account and contact administrators for Git repository collaborator permissions.
# If you are using Windows, you can download the latest version of Git including Bash console from [[http://code.google.com/p/msysgit/downloads/list|here]]. Git should be installed by default for Mac and Linux.
# Follow these [[http://help.github.com/win-set-up-git/|instructions]] to set up your SSH key with Github.
# In command prompt, go to the directory where you want to place the project repository.
# Type ##git clone git@github.com:Elesant/Minerva.git##.
# Now you have the source code for the Minerva project.

=== Setup Database

# Download and install [[http://www.postgresql.org/download/|PostgreSQL]] for your corresponding operating system.
# Open the management console //pgAdmin III//.
# If your //Server Groups// on the left panel is empty, click //File->Add Server// and create a new server with any name and set //Host// to //localhost// and leave //Port// at //5432// and input your password specified during PostgreSQL installation.
# Right click on //Login Roles// on the left panel and click on //New Login Role//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.


=== Install Python Modules

# Download [[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip#downloads|Pip]].
# Go to the downloaded Pip directory and type //python setup.py install//.
# Go to the project directory //Minerva/tools//.
# Type ##pip install -r requirements.txt## to install all required Python modules.
** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)

** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

==== Python Module List

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)
* Docutils (Documentation)
* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Troubleshooting

==== PostgreSQL on Ubuntu

##sudo apt-get install postgresql phppgadmin pgadmin3##

==== Cannot Login to pgAdmin

{{{
sudo -u postgres createuser --superuser any_user_name
sudo -u postgres psql
postgres=# \password any_user_name
}}}
Now you can set a new password for //any_user_name//.

==== Error Installing psycopg2 Python Module

##sudo apt-get install libpq-dev##

==== Database on Different Host & Port

If an error related to database occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. 
{{{
# settings_extra.py
from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host'
DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port'
}}}

# Type //python// in command prompt / terminal to see if Python is already installed.
# If not, download [[http://www.python.org/download/|Python version 2.7.x]] for your corresponding operating system.
# If you are on Windows, you might have to add //path\to\python// and //path\to\python\Scripts// to your system's Path environment variable if they are not there.
** Search //environment// in the search box in Start menu, and then click on //Edit the system environment variables//.
** Under //System variables//, click to edit //Path//.
** Paths are separated by //;//.
# Now type //python// in the command prompt, if you entered the Python shell, you have successfully set up Python and can type //quit()// to exit the shell.

=== Setup Git Project

# Register a [[https://github.com/|Github]] account and contact administrators for Git repository collaborator permissions.
# If you are using Windows, you can download the latest version of Git including Bash console from [[http://code.google.com/p/msysgit/downloads/list|here]]. Git should be installed by default for Mac and Linux.
# Follow these [[http://help.github.com/win-set-up-git/|instructions]] to set up your SSH key with Github.
# In command prompt, go to the directory where you want to place the project repository.
# Type ##git clone git@github.com:Elesant/Minerva.git##.
# Now you have the source code for the Minerva project.

=== Setup Database

# Download and install [[http://www.postgresql.org/download/|PostgreSQL]] for your corresponding operating system.
# Open the management console //pgAdmin III//.
# If your //Server Groups// on the left panel is empty, click //File->Add Server// and create a new server with any name and set //Host// to //localhost// and leave //Port// at //5432// and input your password specified during PostgreSQL installation.
# Right click on //Login Roles// on the left panel and click on //New Login Role//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.

# In command prompt, go to the directory where you want to place the project repository.
# Type ##git clone git@github.com:Elesant/Minerva.git##.
# Now you have the source code for the Minerva project.

=== Setup Database

# Download and install [[http://www.postgresql.org/download/|PostgreSQL]] for your corresponding operating system.
# Open the management console //pgAdmin III//.
# If your //Server Groups// on the left panel is empty, click //File->Add Server// and create a new server with any name and set //Host// to //localhost// and leave //Port// at //5432// and input your password specified during PostgreSQL installation.
# Right click on //Login Roles// on the left panel and click on //New Login Role//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.


=== Install Python Modules

# Download [[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip#downloads|Pip]].
# Go to the downloaded Pip directory and type //python setup.py install//.
# Go to the project directory //Minerva/tools//.
# Type ##pip install -r requirements.txt## to install all required Python modules.
** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

==== Python Module List

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)
* Docutils (Documentation)
* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Troubleshooting

==== PostgreSQL on Ubuntu

##sudo apt-get install postgresql phppgadmin pgadmin3##

==== Cannot Login to pgAdmin

{{{
sudo -u postgres createuser --superuser any_user_name
sudo -u postgres psql
postgres=# \password any_user_name
}}}
Now you can set a new password for //any_user_name//.

==== Error Installing psycopg2 Python Module

##sudo apt-get install python-dev libpq-dev##

==== Permission Denied Errors

Run commands with //sudo//.

==== Database on Different Host & Port

If error related to database authentication failure occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. 
{{{
# settings_extra.py
from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host'
DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port'
}}}

fields.document_from:
=== Get Prepared

* Try out the [[https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.4/|Django]] tutorials.
* The website front end is based on [[http://twitter.github.com/bootstrap/|Bootstrap]].
* The CSS is generated from [[http://lesscss.org/|LESS]] files.
* Acquire basic knowledge of [[http://docs.jquery.com/Tutorials|JQuery]].
* Awesome examples of the [[http://www.dajaxproject.com/|AJAX framework]] we are using.

=== Project Overview

* //bulletin// - code related to the Bulletin component
* //portfolio// - code related to the Portfolio component
* //data// - views which return only data instead of pages
* //homeroom// - code related to the Crowd component
* //account// - code related to an user account, including authentication and registration
* //backstage// - code related to the Backstage component
* //core// - fundamental code required by other components
** //management// - where custom Django management commands go
** //templatetags// - where template tags/filters go
* //course// - code related to course information
* //schoolax// - main website
** //assets// - website's static files
** //fixtures// - partial or complete database dumps
** //templates// - HTML templates which get displayed

=== Changes to Models

* If a change to a model which may affect the database schema is made, we will have to utilize South to migrate the schema and data.
* Pull the latest version of the code (VERY IMPORTANT), so we do not get migration conflicts.
* Type ##python manage.py migrate## to synchronize the database to the latest version.
* Type ##python manage.py schemamigration [the app which the model is in] --auto##.
* Define any required default values.
* Type ##python manage.py migrate## again.
* If no error occurs, you can now commit and push your code along with the generated migration Python files.
* Any other usage can refer to the [[http://south.aeracode.org/docs/index.html|South documentation]].

=== Dump Data Fixture

* Go to project directory //Minerva/tools//.
* Type ##python dumpdata.py##.
* Input a fixture collection name when prompted.
* Wait till the JSON data files are generated.

=== Search Engine

* We are currently using the Whoosh search engine.
* Type ##python manage.py rebuild_index## to rebuild search index.
* Type ##python manage.py update_index## to update search index.

=== Generate CSS Files

* We are using the LESS framework, which needs to be compiled to prepare the CSS files for non-development environments, using LESS compilers.
** [[http://winless.org/|WinLess]] (Windows)
** [[http://crunchapp.net/|Crunch]] (Mac)
** [[http://wearekiss.com/simpless|SimpLess]] (Cross-Platform)
* After installing the LESS compiler, just compile the //minerva.less// file and put the generated //minerva.css// file into the //assets/css// folder.

* To rename a database table:
{{{

# Inside the generated migration file
class Migration(SchemaMigration):
    def forwards(self, orm):
        db.rename_table('yourapp_foo', 'yourapp_bar')
    def backwards(self, orm):
        db.rename_table('yourapp_bar','yourapp_foo') 
}}}

* After installing the LESS compiler, just compile the //minerva.less// file and put the generated //minerva.css// file into the //assets/css// folder.

# In //Properties// tab, set //Role name// to //minerva_admin// and //password// to //1990106// (twice for the two fields). Ignore the rest of the fields.
# In //Role privileges// tab, check all the fields and click //OK//.
# Right click on //Databases// on the left panel and click on //New Database//.
# In //Properties// tab, set //Name// to //minerva// and //Owner// to the just created role //minerva_admin// and click //OK//.


=== Install Python Modules

# Download [[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip#downloads|Pip]].
# Go to the downloaded Pip directory and type //python setup.py install//.
# Go to the project directory //Minerva/tools//.
# Type ##pip install -r requirements.txt## to install all required Python modules.
** Type ##pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt## to upgrade existing modules.
** Type ##pip uninstall -r requirements.txt## to uninstall existing modules.
# In the rare cases, if any of the installations fail, you will have to hunt down the individual modules on the Internet and install manually.

==== Python Module List

* Django (Web Framework)
* Psycopg2 (PostgreSQL Driver)
* South (Database Migration)
* Whoosh (Search Engine)
* Django Haystack (Search Engine Interface)
* Dajaxice (AJAX)
* Dajax (AJAX)
* CreoleParser (Wiki Markup)
* Django Compressor (CSS/JS)
* Pylint (Python Style Check)
* PEP8 (Python Style Check)
* Docutils (Documentation) - NOTE: Has to be installed using Python 3!
* Django Debug Toolbar (Debugging)

=== Setup Database Schema & Data

# Type ##python manage.py syncdb## in the project's main directory to setup necessary schema. Say //no// if asked to create a superuser.
# Type ##python manage.py migrate## to setup the project's necessary schema.
# Type ##python manage.py loaddata QA/all## to load the database with data.

=== Start Development Server

# Type ##python manage.py runserver## to start the development server.
# Go to //127.0.0.1:8000// in your browser.
# If no error occurs, you are set! However, if an error occurs, it will have to be resolved through debugging. If a Python module appears to be missing, you will have to download it and set it up manually. If any problem persists, feel free to contact administrators.
# You can now login to superuser with credential name //admin@schoolax.com// and password //1990106//.

=== Troubleshooting

==== PostgreSQL on Ubuntu

##sudo apt-get install postgresql phppgadmin pgadmin3##

==== Cannot Login to pgAdmin

{{{
sudo -u postgres createuser --superuser any_user_name
sudo -u postgres psql
postgres=# \password any_user_name
}}}
Now you can set a new password for //any_user_name//.

==== Error Installing psycopg2 Python Module

##sudo apt-get install python-dev libpq-dev##

==== Permission Denied Errors

Run commands with //sudo//.

==== Database on Different Host & Port

If error related to database authentication failure occurs, you can add a new setting file named //settings_extra.py// to override your database configuration, such as //HOST// and //PORT//. 
{{{
# settings_extra.py
from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['HOST'] = 'your database host'
DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = 'your database port'
}}}

=== Customized Settings Example

{{{
# Create a settings_extra.py under the same directory as the rest of the settings files

from settings import *

DATABASES['default']['PORT'] = '1337'
SWAP_USER = False
ENABLE_TOOLBAR = True

def toolbar_callback(request):
    return ENABLE_TOOLBAR

DEBUG_TOOLBAR_CONFIG = {
    'INTERCEPT_REDIRECTS': True,
    'SHOW_TOOLBAR_CALLBACK': toolbar_callback,
    'ENABLE_STACKTRACES': True,
}
}}}
